sec.p:
The conversion of (η 5-C 5H 5)Co(PPh 3) 2 ( 1) and TMSC≡C(SOTol) to the cobaltosulfoxide complex (η 5-C 5H 5)Co(PPh 3){S(=O)Tol}(C≡CTMS) ( 2, Tol = p-C 6H 4Me) represents the first unambiguous example of sulfoxide carbon−sulfur bond activation (Scheme 1).( 1) In the presence of oxygen, complex 2 underwent conversion to cobaltosulfone complex (η 5-C 5H 5)Co(PPh 3){S(=O) 2Tol}(C≡CTMS) ( 3), whereas heating solutions of 2 in the absence of oxygen led to the formation of O=PPh 3 and the thiolato-bridged complexes [(η 5-C 5H 5)Co(μ-η 2-STol) 2] 2 ( 4-eq,ax and 4-eq,eq). In an effort to stabilize 2 with respect to formation of 4, we sought to prepare analogues in which the phosphine ligand was replaced by an N-heterocyclic carbene ligand. N-Heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands afford significant advantages over phosphine ligands with respect to ligand donor properties and oxidative stability.( 2) Here we report the synthesis and characterization of the cobalt 1,3-bis(isopropyl)imidazol-2-ylidene (Im
i Pr 2) complexes (η 5-C 5H 5)Co(Im
i Pr 2)(PPh 3) ( 5) and (η 5-C 5H 5)Co(Im
i Pr 2)(CO) ( 6) and conversion of 5 to (η 5-C 5H 5)Co(Im
i Pr 2)(SC 6H 5) ( 7) and (η 5-C 5H 5)Co(Im
i Pr 2)(SO 2C 6H 5) ( 8).

div.div: Synthesis of Cobalt-Sulfenate ( 2), Sulfinate ( 3), and μ-Thiolato ( 4) Complexes
